TopicTitle: What is the point of planetary bases

Articles.Content: Firstly I'm not criticising planetary bases. I'm just curious as to what the point of making them is, I always hear people talking about them. I imagine it would be enjoyable building them and flying them there but what then? what is there to do when they're built. Of course they will serve a purpose with the introduction of career mode with mining, remote launch pads etc. Can someone enlighten me.
For because. That's why I build them, at least.
But to me that makes no sense. I wouldnt put hours into a base "for because". Id like to hear what people use them for.
Well, it keeps you interested in the game because there are barley any features because it's in a Alpha state. Same with space stations and the such
Because... uhm... THEY ARE COOL!

Duna Base Alpha uses one for off-Kerbin rocket missions (it's the core of the base). And one of my two future Laythe bases will use one as a Boat Spawning area, offshore.

I just use them to make it like, that base is independent from Kerbin. Why wait for a transfer window, when I can just spawn it from that base?

If you were talking about bases in general, Duna Base Alpha was made as a science base (and a way to get my Kerbals off my Space Station, since they got bored up there).

My Laythe base.... personal reasons.

Edited July 24, 2013 by Benie

I've put mine on minmus to simulate mining operations on an asteroid... You would need something like 10 kerbals (altought highly robotic ops) to take care of all the machinery and to still have a crew rested and in position in case an emergency arise.

I use the kethane mod btw...

While it's certainly not a planetary base, I built my Space Station Archangel just because I wanted a cool space station in Kerbin orbit. T'was even the first thing I did when I first got KSP; I also learned a whole lot about orbital mechanics and rendezvous and docking maneuvers while I was going about the process of building it.
It's mostly for the challenge, just like everything else we do in KSP. Landing and assembling a planetary base can be quite tricky and is definitely a brag-worthy achievement in my opinion.

But to me that makes no sense. I wouldnt put hours into a base "for because". Id like to hear what people use them for.

They give me a goal. Plus, adding a life support mod makes them especially important since they can function as waystations in faraway places.
Well, since I use Kethane, my bases act as refueling for tankers, which then take it to a waiting station in orbit, which can then refuel any craft heading through the system.

But to me that makes no sense. I wouldnt put hours into a base "for because". Id like to hear what people use them for.

Everything in this game is "for because" until they add a career mode. What's the point of a space station? What's the point of a Mun rover?

Building things and getting them to where you want them to be is the point.
Its like space stations, there fun to build and design, but they really don't do anything. Hopefully this will change when career mode is out.

But to me that makes no sense. I wouldnt put hours into a base "for because". Id like to hear what people use them for.

Because building off-world bases and space stations in your back yard would be silly.

Everything in this game is "for because" until they add a career mode. What's the point of a space station? What's the point of a Mun rover?

Building things and getting them to where you want them to be is the point.

We make bases for the same reason we try to jump craters... It's fun.

The object of building planetary bases is in the accomplishment. Once you have started one on a planet you can opt to just leave it there. Or you can roll play by periodically running supply ships to imagine keeping the base sustainable. I also try to rotate crews every so often.

Its like space stations, there fun to build and design, but they really don't do anything. Hopefully this will change when career mode is out.
